subject: Law
title: Congressional Power: The Commerce Clause
description: A quick win: understand Congressional Power: The Commerce Clause.

hook.text: A farmer grew wheat for his own chickens. The federal government fined him. The Supreme Court said that was legal.

buildup.text: The Commerce Clause gives Congress power to regulate commerce 'among the several States.'

discovery.text: In Wickard v. Filburn (1942), the Court ruled that even personal farming affects interstate commerce.

twist.text: This interpretation massively expanded federal power. Almost any economic activity could be regulated.

climax.text: But in 1995, United States v. Lopez drew a line: guns near schools weren't commerce. Limits still exist.

punchline.text: The Commerce Clause stretched far, but not infinitely.

quiz.question: Which case expanded the Commerce Clause to personal farming?
